speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: My Lord of Suffolke, within foureteene dayes
At Briſtow I expeƈt my Souldiers,
For there Ile ſhippe them all for Ireland.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Ile ſee it truly done, my Lord of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Now Yorke, or neuer, ſteele thy fearfull thoughts,
And change miſdoubt to reſolution;
Be that thou hop’ſt to be, or what thou art;
Reſigne to death, it is not worth th’ enioying:
Let pale-fac’t feare keepe with the meane-borne man,
And ﬁnde no harbor in a Royall heart.
Faſter thē Spring-time ſhowres, comes thoght on thoght,
And not a thought, but thinkes on Dignitie.
My Brayne, more buſie then the laboring Spider,
Weaues tedious Snares to trap mine Enemies.
Well Nobles, well: ’tis politikely done,
To ſend me packing with an Hoaſt of men:
I feare me, you but warme the ſtarued Snake,
Who cheriſht in your breaſts, will ſting your hearts.
’Twas men I lackt, and you will giue them me;
I take it kindly: yet be well aſſur’d,
You put ſharpe Weapons in a mad-mans hands.
Whiles I in Ireland nouriſh a mightie Band,
I will ſtirre vp in England ſome black Storme,
Shall blowe ten thouſand Soules to Heauen, or Hell:
And this fell Tempeſt ſhall not ceaſe to rage,
Vntill the Golden Circuit on my Head,
Like to the glorious Sunnes tranſparant Beames,
Doe calme the furie of this mad-bred Flawe.
And for a miniſter of my intent,
I haue ſeduc’d a head-ſtrong Kentiſhman,
Iohn Cade of Aſhford,
To make Commotion, as full well he can,
Vnder the title of Iohn Mortimer.
In Ireland haue I ſeene this ſtubborne Cade
Oppoſe himſelfe againſt a Troupe of Kernes,
And fought ſo long, till that his thighes with Darts
Were almoſt like a ſharpe-quill’d Porpentine:
And in the end being reſcued, I haue ſeene
Him capre vpright, like a wilde Moriſco,
Shaking the bloody Darts, as he his Bells.
Full often, like a ſhag-hayr’d craftie Kerne,
Hath he conuerſed with the Enemie,
And vndiſcouer’d, come to me againe,
And giuen me notice of their Villanies.
This Deuill here ſhall be my ſubſtitute;
For that Iohn Mortimer, which now is dead,
In face, in gate, in ſpeech he doth reſemble.
By this, I ſhall perceiue the Commons minde,
How they affeƈt the Houſe and Clayme of Yorke.
Say he be taken, rackt, and tortured;
I know, no paine they can inﬂiƈt vpon him,
Will make him ſay, I mou’d him to thoſe Armes.
Say that he thriue, as ’tis great like he will,
Why then from Ireland come I with my ſtrength,
And reape the Harueſt which that Raſcall ſow’d.
For Humfrey; being dead, as he ſhall be,
And Henry put apart: the next for me.

scene.stagedir: Enter two or three running ouer the Stage, from the Murther of Duke Humfrey.

speech.line: Runne to my Lord of Suffolke: let him know
We haue diſpatcht the Duke, as he commanded.
Oh, that it were to doe: what haue we done?
Didſt euer heare a man ſo penitent?
Here comes my Lord.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Now Sirs, haue you diſpatcht this thing?
I, my good Lord, hee’s dead.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Why that’s well ſaid. Goe, get you to my Houſe,
I will reward you for this venturous deed:
The King and all the Peeres are here at hand.
Haue you layd faire the Bed? Is all things well,
According as I gaue direƈtions?
’Tis, my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Away, be gone.

scene.stagedir: Sound Trumpets. Enter the King, the Queene, Cardinall, Suffolke, Somerſet, with Attendants.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Goe call our Vnckle to our preſence ſtraight:
Say, we intend to try his Grace to day,
If he be guiltie, as ’tis publiſhed.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Ile call him preſently, my Noble Lord.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Lords take your places: and I pray you all
Proceed no ſtraiter ’gainſt our Vnckle Gloſter,
Then from true euidence, of good eſteeme,
He be approu’d in praƈtiſe culpable.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: God forbid any Malice ſhould preuayle,
That faultleſſe may condemne a Noble man:
Pray God he may acquit him of ſuſpition.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I thanke thee Nell, theſe wordes content mee.
much.
How now? why look’ſt thou pale? why trembleſt thou?
Where is our Vnckle? what’s the matter, Suffolke?

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Dead in his Bed, my Lord: Gloſter is dead.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Marry God forfend.

speech.speaker: Card.
speech.line: Gods ſecret Iudgement: I did dreame to Night,
The Duke was dumbe, and could not ſpeake a word.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: How fares my Lord? Helpe Lords, the King is
dead.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Rere vp his Body, wring him by the Noſe.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Runne, goe, helpe, helpe: Oh Henry ope thine eyes.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: He doth reuiue againe, Madame be patient.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Oh Heauenly God.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: How fares my gracious Lord?

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Comfort my Soueraigne, gracious Henry com-
fort.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What, doth my Lord of Suffolke comfort me?
Came he right now to ſing a Rauens Note,
Whoſe diſmall tune bereft my Vitall powres:
And thinkes he, that the chirping of a Wren,
By crying comfort from a hollow breaſt,
Can chaſe away the ﬁrſt-conceiued ſound?
Hide not thy poyſon with ſuch ſugred words,
Lay not thy hands on me: forbeare I ſay,
Their touch affrights me as a Serpents ſting.
Thou balefull Meſſenger, out of my ſight:
Vpon thy eye-balls, murderous Tyrannie
Sits in grim Maieſtie, to fright the World.
Looke not vpon me, for thine eyes are wounding;
Yet doe not goe away: come Baſiliske,
And kill the innocent gazer with thy ſight:
For in the ſhade of death, I ſhall ﬁnde ioy;
In life, but double death, now Gloſter’s dead.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Why do you rate my Lord of Suffolke thus?
Although the Duke was enemie to him,
Yet he moſt Chriſtian-like laments his death:
And for my ſelfe, Foe as he was to me,
Might liquid teares, or heart-offending groanes,
Or blood-conſuming ſighes recall his Life;
I would be blinde with weeping, ſicke with grones,
Looke pale as Prim-roſe with blood-drinking ſighes,
And all to haue the Noble Duke aliue.
What know I how the world may deeme of me?
For it is knowne we were but hollow Friends:
It may be iudg’d I made the Duke away,
So ſhall my name with Slanders tongue be wounded,
And Princes Courts be ﬁll’d with my reproach:
This get I by his death: Aye me vnhappie,
To be a Queene, and Crown’d with infamie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Ah woe is me for Gloſter, wretched man.

speech.speaker: Queen.
speech.line: Be woe for me, more wretched then he is.
What, Doſt thou turne away, and hide thy face?
I am no loathſome Leaper, looke on me.
What? Art thou like the Adder waxen deafe?
Be poyſonous too, and kill thy forlorne Queene.
Is all thy comfort ſhut in Gloſters Tombe?
Why then Dame Elianor was neere thy ioy.
Ereƈt his Statue, and worſhip it,
And make my Image but an Ale-houſe ſigne.
Was I for this nye wrack’d vpon the Sea,
And twice by aukward winde from Englands banke
Droue backe againe vnto my Natiue Clime.
What boaded this? but well fore-warning winde
Did ſeeme to ſay, ſeeke not a Scorpions Neſt,
Nor ſet no footing on this vnkinde Shore.
What did I then? But curſt the gentle guſts,
And he that loos’d them forth their Brazen Caues,
And bid them blow towards Englands bleſſed ſhore,
Or turne our Sterne vpon a dreadfull Rocke:
Yet Æolus would not be a murtherer,
But left that hatefull ofﬁce vnto thee.
The pretty vaulting Sea refus’d to drowne me,
Knowing that thou wouldſt haue me drown’d on ſhore
With teares as ſalt as Sea, through thy vnkindneſſe.
The ſplitting Rockes cowr’d in the ſinking ſands,
And would not daſh me with their ragged ſides,
Becauſe thy ﬂinty heart more hard then they,
Might in thy Pallace, periſh Elianor.
As farre as I could ken thy Chalky Cliffes,
When from thy Shore, the Tempeſt beate vs backe,
I ſtood vpon the Hatches in the ſtorme:
And when the duskie sky, began to rob
My earneſt-gaping-ſight of thy Lands view,
I tooke a coſtly Iewell from my necke,
A Hart it was bound in with Diamonds,
And threw it towards thy Land: The Sea receiu’d it,
And ſo I wiſh’d thy body might my Heart:
And euen with this, I loſt faire Englands view,
And bid mine eyes be packing with my Heart,
And call’d them blinde and duskie Speƈtacles,
For looſing ken of Albions wiſhed Coaſt.
How often haue I tempted Suffolkes tongue
(The agent of thy foule inconſtancie)
To ſit and watch me as Aſcanius did,
When he to madding Dido would vnfold
His Fathers Aƈts, commenc’d in burning Troy.
Am I not witcht like her? Or thou not falſe like him?
Aye me, I can no more: Dye Elinor,
For Henry weepes, that thou doſt liue ſo long.

scene.stagedir: Noyſe within. Enter Warwicke, and many Commons.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: It is reported, mighty Soueraigne,
That good Duke Humfrey Traiterouſly is murdred
By Suffolke, and the Cardinall Beaufords meanes:
The Commons like an angry Hiue of Bees
That want their Leader, ſcatter vp and downe,
And care not who they ſting in his reuenge.
My ſelfe haue calm’d their ſpleenfull mutinie,
Vntill they heare the order of his death.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: That he is dead good Warwick, ’tis too true,
But how he dyed, God knowes, not Henry:
Enter his Chamber, view his breathleſſe Corpes,
And comment then vpon his ſodaine death.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: That ſhall I do my Liege; Stay Salsburie
With the rude multitude, till I returne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: O thou that iudgeſt all things, ſtay my thoghts:
My thoughts, that labour to perſwade my ſoule,
Some violent hands were laid on Humfries life:
If my ſuſpeƈt be falſe, forgiue me God,
For iudgement onely doth belong to thee:
Faine would I go to chafe his palie lips,
With twenty thouſand kiſſes, and to draine
Vpon his face an Ocean of ſalt teares,
To tell my loue vnto his dumbe deafe trunke,
And with my ﬁngers feele his hand, vnfeeling:
But all in vaine are theſe meane Obſequies,
And to ſuruey his dead and earthy Image:
What were it but to make my ſorrow greater?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Come hither gracious Soueraigne, view this
body.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: That is to ſee how deepe my graue is made,
For with his ſoule ﬂed all my worldly ſolace:
For ſeeing him, I ſee my life in death.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: As ſurely as my ſoule intends to liue
With that dread King that tooke our ſtate vpon him,
To free vs from his Fathers wrathfull curſe,
I do beleeue that violent hands were laid
Vpon the life of this thrice-famed Duke.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: A dreadfull Oath, ſworne with a ſolemn tongue:
What inſtance giues Lord Warwicke for his vow.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: See how the blood is ſetled in his face.
Oft haue I ſeene a timely-parted Ghoſt,
Of aſhy ſemblance, meager, pale, and bloodleſſe,
Being all deſcended to the labouring heart,
Who in the Conﬂiƈt that it holds with death,
Attraƈts the ſame for aydance ’gainſt the enemy,
Which with the heart there cooles, and ne’re returneth,
To bluſh and beautiﬁe the Cheeke againe.
But ſee, his face is blacke, and full of blood:
His eye-balles further out, than when he liued,
Staring full gaſtly, like a ſtrangled man:
His hayre vprear’d, his noſtrils ſtretcht with ſtrugling:
His hands abroad diſplay’d, as one that graſpt
And tugg’d for Life, and was by ſtrength ſubdude.
Looke on the ſheets his haire (you ſee) is ſticking,
His well proportion’d Beard, made ruffe and rugged,
Like to the Summers Corne by Tempeſt lodged:
It cannot be but he was murdred heere,
The leaſt of all theſe ſignes were probable.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: Why Warwicke, who ſhould do the D. to death?
My ſelfe and Beauford had him in proteƈtion,
And we I hope ſir, are no murtherers.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: But both of you were vowed D. Humfries foes,
And you (forſooth) had the good Duke to keepe:
Tis like you would not feaſt him like a friend,
And ’tis well ſeene, he found an enemy.

speech.speaker: Queen.
speech.line: Than you belike ſuſpeƈt theſe Noblemen,
As guilty of Duke Humfries timeleſſe death.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Who ﬁnds the Heyfer dead, and bleeding freſh,
And ſees faſt-by, a Butcher with an Axe,
But will ſuſpeƈt, ’twas he that made the ſlaughter?
Who ﬁnds the Partridge in the Puttocks Neſt,
But may imagine how the Bird was dead,
Although the Kyte ſoare with vnbloudied Beake?
Euen ſo ſuſpitious is this Tragedie.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Are you the Butcher, Suffolk? where’s your Knife?
Is Beauford tearm’d a Kyte? where are his Tallons?

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: I weare no Knife, to ſlaughter ſleeping men,
But here’s a vengefull Sword, ruſted with eaſe,
That ſhall be ſcowred in his rancorous heart,
That ſlanders me with Murthers Crimſon Badge.
Say, if thou dar’ſt, prowd Lord of Warwickſhire,
That I am faultie in Duke Humfreyes death.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: What dares not Warwick, if falſe Suffolke dare
him?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: He dares not calme his contumelious Spirit,
Nor ceaſe to be an arrogant Controller,
Though Suffolke dare him twentie thouſand times.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Madame be ſtill: with reuerence may I ſay,
For euery word you ſpeake in his behalfe,
Is ſlander to your Royall Dignitie.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Blunt-witted Lord, ignoble in demeanor,
If euer Lady wrong’d her Lord ſo much,
Thy Mother tooke into her blamefull Bed
Some ſterne vntutur’d Churle; and Noble Stock
Was graft with Crab-tree ſlippe, whoſe Fruit thou art,
And neuer of the Neuils Noble Race.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: But that the guilt of Murther bucklers thee,
And I ſhould rob the Deaths-man of his Fee,
Quitting thee thereby of ten thouſand ſhames,
And that my Soueraignes preſence makes me milde,
I would, falſe murd’rous Coward, on thy Knee
Make thee begge pardon for thy paſſed ſpeech,
And ſay, it was thy Mother that thou meant’ſt,
That thou thy ſelfe waſt borne in Baſtardie;
And after all this fearefull Homage done,
Giue thee thy hyre, and ſend thy Soule to Hell,
Pernicious blood-ſucker of ſleeping men.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Thou ſhalt be waking, while I ſhed thy blood,
If from this preſence thou dar’ſt goe with me.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Away euen now, or I will drag thee hence:
Vnworthy though thou art, Ile cope with thee,
And doe ſome ſeruice to Duke Humfreyes Ghoſt.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What ſtronger Breſt-plate then a heart vntainted?
Thrice is he arm’d, that hath his Quarrell iuſt;
And he but naked, though lockt vp in Steele,
Whoſe Conſcience with Iniuſtice is corrupted.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: What noyſe is this?

scene.stagedir: Enter Suffolke and Warwicke, with their Weapons drawne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why how now Lords?
Your wrathfull Weapons drawne,
Here in our preſence? Dare you be ſo bold?
Why what tumultuous clamor haue we here?

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: The trayt’rous Warwick, with the men of Bury,
Set all vpon me, mightie Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: Salisb.
speech.line: Sirs ſtand apart, the King ſhall know your
minde.
Dread Lord, the Commons ſend you word by me,
Vnleſſe Lord Suffolke ſtraight be done to death,
Or baniſhed faire Englands Territories,
They will by violence teare him from your Pallace,
And torture him with grieuous lingring death.
They ſay, by him the good Duke Humfrey dy’de:
They ſay, in him they feare your Highneſſe death;
And meere inſtinƈt of Loue and Loyaltie,
Free from a ſtubborne oppoſite intent,
As being thought to contradiƈt your liking,
Makes them thus forward in his Baniſhment.
They ſay, in care of your moſt Royall Perſon,
That if your Highneſſe ſhould intend to ſleepe,
And charge, that no man ſhould diſturbe your reſt,
In paine of your diſlike, or paine of death;
Yet not withſtanding ſuch a ſtrait Ediƈt,
Were there a Serpent ſeene, with forked Tongue,
That ſlyly glyded towards your Maieſtie,
It were but neceſſarie you were wak’t:
Leaſt being ſuffer’d in that harmefull ſlumber,
The mortall Worme might make the ſleepe eternall.
And therefore doe they cry, though you forbid,
That they will guard you, where you will, or no,
From ſuch fell Serpents as falſe Suffolke is;
With whoſe inuenomed and fatall ſting,
Your louing Vnckle, twentie times his worth,
They ſay is ſhamefully bereft of life.

speech.speaker: Commons within.
speech.line: An anſwer from the King, my Lord
of Salisbury.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: ’Tis like the Commons, rude vnpoliſht Hindes,
Could ſend ſuch Meſſage to their Soueraigne:
But you, my Lord, were glad to be imploy’d,
To ſhew how queint an Orator you are.
But all the Honor Salisbury hath wonne,
Is, that he was the Lord Embaſſador,
Sent from a ſort of Tinkers to the King.

speech.speaker: Within.
speech.line: An anſwer from the King, or wee will all
breake in.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Goe Salisbury, and tell them all from me,
I thanke them for their tender louing care;
And had I not beene cited ſo by them,
Yet did I purpoſe as they doe entreat:
For ſure, my thoughts doe hourely prophecie,
Miſchance vnto my State by Suffolkes meanes.
And therefore by his Maieſtie I ſweare,
Whoſe farre-vnworthie Deputie I am,
He ſhall not breathe infeƈtion in this ayre,
But three dayes longer, on the paine of death.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Oh Henry, let me pleade for gentle Suffolke.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Vngentle Queene, to call him gentle Suffolke.
No more I ſay: if thou do’ſt pleade for him,
Thou wilt but adde encreaſe vnto my Wrath.
Had I but ſayd, I would haue kept my Word;
But when I ſweare, it is irreuocable:
If after three dayes ſpace thou here bee’ſt found,
On any ground that I am Ruler of,
The World ſhall not be Ranſome for thy Life.
Come Warwicke, come good Warwicke, goe with mee,
I haue great matters to impart to thee.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Miſchance and Sorrow goe along with you,
Hearts Diſcontent, and ſowre Afﬂiƈtion,
Be play-fellowes to keepe you companie:
There’s two of you, the Deuill make a third,
And three-fold Vengeance tend vpon your ſteps.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Ceaſe, gentle Queene, theſe Execrations,
And let thy Suffolke take his heauie leaue.

speech.speaker: Queen.
speech.line: Fye Coward woman, and ſoft harted wretch,
Haſt thou not ſpirit to curſe thine enemy.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: A plague vpon them: wherefore ſhould I curſſe
them?
Would curſes kill, as doth the Mandrakes grone,
I would inuent as bitter ſearching termes,
As curſt, as harſh, and horrible to heare,
Deliuer’d ſtrongly through my ﬁxed teeth,
With full as many ſignes of deadly hate,
As leane-fac’d enuy in her loathſome caue.
My tongue ſhould ſtumble in mine earneſt words,
Mine eyes ſhould ſparkle like the beaten Flint,
Mine haire be ﬁxt an end, as one diſtraƈt:
I, euery ioynt ſhould ſeeme to curſe and ban,
And euen now my burthen’d heart would breake
Should I not curſe them. Poyſon be their drinke.
Gall, worſe then Gall, the daintieſt that they taſte:
Their ſweeteſt ſhade, a groue of Cypreſſe Trees:
Their cheefeſt Proſpeƈt, murd’ring Baſiliskes:
Their ſofteſt Touch, as ſmart as Lyzards ſtings:
Their Muſicke, frightfull as the Serpents hiſſe,
And boading Screech-Owles, make the Conſort full.
All the foule terrors in darke ſeated hell ―

speech.speaker: Q.
speech.line: Enough ſweet Suffolke, thou torment’ſt thy ſelfe,
And theſe dread curſes like the Sunne ’gainſt glaſſe,
Or like an ouer-charged Gun, recoile,
And turnes the force of them vpon thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: You bad me ban, and will you bid me leaue?
Now by the ground that I am baniſh’d from,
Well could I curſe away a Winters night,
Though ſtanding naked on a Mountaine top,
Where byting cold would neuer let graſſe grow,
And thinke it but a minute ſpent in ſport.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Oh, let me intreat thee ceaſe, giue me thy hand,
That I may dew it with my mournfull teares:
Nor let the raine of heauen wet this place,
To waſh away my wofull Monuments.
Oh, could this kiſſe be printed in thy hand,
That thou might’ſt thinke vpon theſe by the Seale,
Through whom a thouſand ſighes are breath’d for thee.
So get thee gone, that I may know my greefe,
’Tis but ſurmiz’d, whiles thou art ſtanding by,
As one that ſurfets, thinking on a want:
I will repeale thee, or be well aſſur’d,
Aduenture to be baniſhed my ſelfe:
And baniſhed I am, if but from thee.
Go, ſpeake not to me; euen now be gone.
Oh go not yet. Euen thus, two Friends condemn’d,
Embrace, and kiſſe, and take ten thouſand leaues,
Loather a hundred times to part then dye;
Yet now farewell, and farewell Life with thee.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: Thus is poore Suffolke ten times baniſhed,
Once by the King, and three times thrice by thee.
’Tis not the Land I care for, wer’t thou thence,
A Wilderneſſe is populous enough,
So Suffolke had thy heauenly company:
For where thou art, there is the World it ſelfe,
With euery ſeuerall pleaſure in the World:
And where thou art not, Deſolation.
I can no more: Liue thou to ioy thy life;
My ſelfe no ioy in nought, but that thou liu’ſt.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Whether goes Vaux ſo faſt? What newes I
prethee?

speech.speaker: Vaux.
speech.line: To ſigniﬁe vnto his Maieſty,
That Cardinal Beauford is at point of death:
For ſodainly a greeuous ſickneſſe tooke him,
That makes him gaspe, and ſtare, and catch the aire,
Blaſpheming God, and curſing men on earth.
Sometime he talkes, as if Duke Humfries Ghoſt
Were by his ſide: Sometime, he calles the King,
And whiſpers to his pillow, as to him,
The ſecrets of his ouer-charged ſoule,
And I am ſent to tell his Maieſtie,
That euen now he cries alowd for him.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Go tell this heauy Meſſage to the King.
Aye me! What is this World? What newes are theſe?
But wherefore greeue I at an houres poore loſſe,
Omitting Suffolkes exile, my ſoules Treaſure?
Why onely Suffolke mourne I not for thee?
And with the Southerne clouds, contend in teares?
Theirs for the earths encreaſe, mine for my ſorrowes.
Now get thee hence, the King thou know’ſt is comming,
If thou be found by me, thou art but dead.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: If I depart from thee, I cannot liue,
And in thy ſight to dye, what were it elſe,
But like a pleaſant ſlumber in thy lap?
Heere could I breath my ſoule into the ayre,
As milde and gentle as the Cradle-babe,
Dying with mothers dugge betweene it’s lips.
Where from thy ſight, I ſhould be raging mad,
And cry out for thee to cloſe vp mine eyes:
To haue thee with thy lippes to ſtop my mouth:
So ſhould’ſt thou eyther turne my ﬂying ſoule,
Or I ſhould breathe it ſo into thy body,
And then it liu’d in ſweete Elizium.
To dye by thee, were but to dye in ieſt,
From thee to dye, were torture more then death:
Oh let me ſtay, befall what may befall.

speech.speaker: Queen.
speech.line: Away: Though parting be a fretfull coroſiue,
It is applyed to a deathfull wound.
To France ſweet Suffolke: Let me heare from thee:
For whereſoere thou art in this worlds Globe,
Ile haue an Iris that ſhall ﬁnde thee out.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: I go.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: And take my heart with thee.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: A Iewell lockt into the wofulſt Caske,
That euer did containe a thing of worth,
Euen as a ſplitted Barke, ſo ſunder we:
This way fall I to death.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: This way for me.

scene.stagedir: Enter the King, Salisbury, and Warwicke, to the Cardinal in bed.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How fare’s my Lord? Speake Beauford to thy
Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: Ca.
speech.line: If thou beeſt death, Ile giue thee Englands Treaſure,
Enough to purchaſe ſuch another Iſland,
So thou wilt let me liue, and feele no paine.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Ah, what a ſigne it is of euill life,
Where death’s approach is ſeene ſo terrible.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Beauford, it is thy Soueraigne ſpeakes to thee.

speech.speaker: Beau.
speech.line: Bring me vnto my Triall when you will.
Dy’de he not in his bed? Where ſhould he dye?
Can I make men liue where they will or no?
Oh torture me no more, I will confeſſe.
Aliue againe? Then ſhew me where he is,
Ile giue a thouſand pound to looke vpon him.
He hath no eyes, the duſt hath blinded them.
Combe downe his haire; looke, looke, it ſtands vpright,
Like Lime-twigs ſet to catch my winged ſoule:
Giue me ſome drinke, and bid the Apothecarie
Bring the ſtrong poyſon that I bought of him.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Oh thou eternall mouer of the heauens,
Looke with a gentle eye vpon this Wretch,
Oh beate away the buſie medling Fiend,
That layes ſtrong ſiege vnto this wretches ſoule,
And from his boſome purge this blacke diſpaire.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: See how the pangs of death do make him grin.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Diſturbe him not, let him paſſe peaceably.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Peace to his ſoule, if Gods good pleaſure be.
Lord Card’nall, if thou think’ſt on heauens bliſſe,
Hold vp thy hand, make ſignall of thy hope.
He dies and makes no ſigne: Oh God forgiue him.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: So bad a death, argues a monſtrous life.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Forbeare to iudge, for we are ſinners all.
Cloſe vp his eyes, and draw the Curtaine cloſe,
And let vs all to Meditation.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Fight at Sea. Ordnance goes off.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: The gaudy blabbing and remorſefull day,
Is crept into the boſome of the Sea:
And now loud houling Wolues arouſe the Iades
That dragge the Tragicke melancholy night:
Who with their drowſie, ſlow, and ﬂagging wings
Cleape dead-mens graues, and from their miſty Iawes,
Breath foule contagious darkneſſe in the ayre:
Therefore bring forth the Souldiers of our prize,
For whilſt our Pinnace Anchors in the Downes,
Heere ſhall they make their ranſome on the ſand,
Or with their blood ſtaine this diſcoloured ſhore.
Maiſter, this Priſoner freely giue I thee,
And thou that art his Mate, make boote of this:
The other Walter Whitmore is thy ſhare.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: What is my ranſome Maſter, let me know.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: A thouſand Crownes, or elſe lay down your head

speech.speaker: Mate.
speech.line: And ſo much ſhall you giue, or off goes yours.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: What thinke you much to pay 2000. Crownes,
And beare the name and port of Gentlemen?
Cut both the Villaines throats, for dy you ſhall:
The liues of thoſe which we haue loſt in ﬁght,
Be counter-poys’d with ſuch a pettie ſumme.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: Ile giue it ſir, and therefore ſpare my life.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: And ſo will I, and write home for it ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Whitm.
speech.line: I loſt mine eye in laying the prize aboord,
And therefore to reuenge it, ſhalt thou dye,
And ſo ſhould theſe, if I might haue my will.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Be not ſo raſh, take ranſome, let him liue.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: Looke on my George, I am a Gentleman,
Rate me at what thou wilt, thou ſhalt be payed.

speech.speaker: Whit.
speech.line: And ſo am I: my name is Walter Whitmore.
How now? why ſtarts thou? What doth death affright?

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: Thy name affrights me, in whoſe ſound is death:
A cunning man did calculate my birth,
And told me that by Water I ſhould dye:
Yet let not this make thee be bloody-minded,
Thy name is Gualtier, being rightly ſounded.

speech.speaker: Whit.
speech.line: Gualtier or Walter, which it is I care not,
Neuer yet did baſe diſhonour blurre our name,
But with our ſword we wip’d away the blot.
Therefore, when Merchant-like I ſell reuenge,
Broke be my ſword, my Armes torne and defac’d,
And I proclaim’d a Coward through the world.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: Stay Whitmore, for thy Priſoner is a Prince,
The Duke of Suffolke, William de la Pole.

speech.speaker: Whit.
speech.line: The Duke of Suffolke, mufﬂed vp in ragges?

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: I, but theſe ragges are no part of the Duke.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: But Ioue was neuer ſlaine as thou ſhalt be,
Obſcure and lowſie Swaine, King Henries blood.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: The honourable blood of Lancaſter
Muſt not be ſhed by ſuch a iaded Groome:
Haſt thou not kiſt thy hand, and held my ſtirrop?
Bare-headed plodded by my foot-cloth Mule,
And thought thee happy when I ſhooke my head.
How often haſt thou waited at my cup,
Fed from my Trencher, kneel’d downe at the boord,
When I haue feaſted with Queene Margaret?
Remember it, and let it make thee Creſt-falne,
I, and alay this thy abortiue Pride:
How in our voyding Lobby haſt thou ſtood,
And duly wayted for my comming forth?
This hand of mine hath writ in thy behalfe,
And therefore ſhall it charme thy riotous tongue.

speech.speaker: Whit.
speech.line: Speak Captaine, ſhall I ſtab the forlorn Swain.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Firſt let my words ſtab him, as he hath me.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: Baſe ſlaue, thy words are blunt, and ſo art thou.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Conuey him hence, and on our long boats ſide,
Strike off his head.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: Thou dar’ſt not for thy owne.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Poole, Sir Poole? Lord,
I kennell, puddle, ſinke, whoſe ﬁlth and dirt
Troubles the ſiluer Spring, where England drinkes:
Now will I dam vp this thy yawning mouth,
For ſwallowing the Treaſure of the Realme.
Thy lips that kiſt the Queene, ſhall ſweepe the ground:
And thou that ſmil’dſt at good Duke Humfries death,
Againſt the ſenſeleſſe windes ſhall grin in vaine,
Who in contempt ſhall hiſſe at thee againe.
And wedded be thou to the Hagges of hell,
For daring to affye a mighty Lord
Vnto the daughter of a worthleſſe King,
Hauing neyther Subieƈt, Wealth, nor Diadem:
By diuelliſh policy art thou growne great,
And like ambitious Sylla ouer-gorg’d,
With gobbets of thy Mother-bleeding heart.
By thee Aniou and Maine were ſold to France.
The falſe reuolting Normans thorough thee,
Diſdaine to call vs Lord, and Piccardie
Hath ſlaine their Gouernors, ſurpriz’d our Forts,
And ſent the ragged Souldiers wounded home.
The Princely Warwicke, and the Neuils all,
Whoſe dreadfull ſwords were neuer drawne in vaine,
As hating thee, and riſing vp in armes.
And now the Houſe of Yorke thruſt from the Crowne,
By ſhamefull murther of a guiltleſſe King,
And lofty proud incroaching tyranny,
Burnes with reuenging ﬁre, whoſe hopefull colours
Aduance our halfe-fac’d Sunne, ſtriuing to ſhine;
Vnder the which is writ, Inuitis nubibus.
The Commons heere in Kent are vp in armes,
And to conclude, Reproach and Beggerie,
Is crept into the Pallace of our King,
And all by thee: away, conuey him hence.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: O that I were a God, to ſhoot forth Thunder
Vpon theſe paltry, ſeruile, abieƈt Drudges:
Small things make baſe men proud. This Villaine heere,
Being Captaine of a Pinnace, threatens more
Then Bargulus the ſtrong Illyrian Pyrate.
Drones ſucke not Eagles blood, but rob Bee-hiues:
It is impoſſible that I ſhould dye
By ſuch a lowly Vaſſall as thy ſelfe.
Thy words moue Rage, and not remorſe in me:
I go of Meſſage from the Queene to France:
I charge thee waft me ſafely croſſe the Channell.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Water: W. Come Suffolke, I muſt waft thee
to thy death.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: Pine gelidus timor occupat artus, it is thee I feare.

speech.speaker: Wal.
speech.line: Thou ſhalt haue cauſe to feare before I leaue thee.
What, are ye danted now? Now will ye ſtoope.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: My gracious Lord intreat him, ſpeak him fair.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: Suffolkes Imperiall tongue is ſterne and rough:
Vs’d to command, vntaught to pleade for fauour.
Farre be it, we ſhould honor ſuch as theſe
With humble ſuite: no, rather let my head
Stoope to the blocke, then theſe knees bow to any,
Saue to the God of heauen, and to my King:
And ſooner dance vpon a bloody pole,
Then ſtand vncouer’d to the Vulgar Groome.
True Nobility, is exempt from feare:
More can I beare, then you dare execute.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Hale him away, and let him talke no more:
Come Souldiers, ſhew what cruelty ye can.

speech.speaker: Suf.
speech.line: That this my death may neuer be forgot.
Great men oft dye by vilde Bezonions.
A Romane Sworder, and Bandetto ſlaue
Murder’d ſweet Tully. Brutus Baſtard hand
Stab’d Iulius Cæſar. Sauage Iſlanders
Pompey the Great, and Suffolke dyes by Pyrats.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: And as for theſe whoſe ranſome we haue ſet,
It is our pleaſure one of them depart:
Therefore come you with vs, and let him go.

scene.stagedir: Manet the ﬁrſt Gent. Enter Walter with the body.

speech.speaker: Wal.
speech.line: There let his head, and liueleſſe bodie lye,
Vntill the Queene his Miſtris bury it.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: O barbarous and bloudy ſpeƈtacle,
His body will I beare vnto the King:
If he reuenge it not, yet will his Friends,
So will the Queene, that liuing, held him deere.

speech.speaker: Beuis.
speech.line: Come and get thee a ſword, though made of a
Lath, they haue bene vp theſe two dayes.

speech.speaker: Hol.
speech.line: They haue the more neede to ſleepe now then.

speech.speaker: Beuis.
speech.line: I tell thee, Iacke Cade the Cloathier, meanes to
dreſſe the Common-wealth and turne it, and ſet a new
nap vpon it.

speech.speaker: Hol.
speech.line: So he had need, for ’tis thred-bare. Well, I ſay,
it was neuer merrie world in England, ſince Gentlemen
came vp.

speech.speaker: Beuis.
speech.line: O miſerable Age: Vertue is not regarded in
Handy-crafts men.

speech.speaker: Hol.
speech.line: The Nobilitie thinke ſcorne to goe in Leather
Aprons.

speech.speaker: Beuis.
speech.line: Nay more, the Kings Councell are no good
Workemen.

speech.speaker: Hol.
speech.line: True: and yet it is ſaid, Labour in thy Vocati-
on: which is as much to ſay, as let the Magiſtrates be la-
bouring men, and therefore ſhould we be Magiſtrates.

speech.speaker: Beuis.
speech.line: Thou haſt hit it: for there’s no better ſigne of a
braue minde, then a hard hand.

speech.speaker: Hol.
speech.line: I ſee them, I ſee them: There’s Beſts Sonne, the
Tanner of Wingham.

speech.speaker: Beuis.
speech.line: Hee ſhall haue the skinnes of our enemies, to
make Dogges Leather of.

speech.speaker: Hol.
speech.line: And Dicke the Butcher.

speech.speaker: Beuis.
speech.line: Then is ſin ſtrucke downe like an Oxe, and ini-
quities throate cut like a Calfe.

speech.speaker: Hol.
speech.line: And Smith the Weauer.

speech.speaker: Beu.
speech.line: Argo, their thred of life is ſpun.

speech.speaker: Hol.
speech.line: Come, come, let’s fall in with them.

scene.stagedir: Drumme. Enter Cade, Dicke Butcher, Smith the Weauer, and a Sawyer, with inﬁnite numbers.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Wee Iohn Cade, ſo tearm’d of our ſuppoſed Fa-
ther.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: Or rather of ſtealing a Cade of Herrings.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: For our enemies ſhall faile before vs, inſpired
with the ſpirit of putting down Kings and Princes. Com-
mand ſilence.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: Silence.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: My Father was a Mortimer.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: He was an honeſt man, and a good Bricklayer.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: My mother a Plantagenet.

speech.speaker: Butch.
speech.line: I knew her well, ſhe was a Midwife.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: My wife deſcended of the Lacies.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: She was indeed a Pedlers daughter, & ſold many
Laces.

speech.speaker: Weauer.
speech.line: But now of late, not able to trauell with her
furr’d Packe, ſhe waſhes buckes here at home.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Therefore am I of an honorable houſe.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: I by my faith, the ﬁeld is honourable, and there
was he borne, vnder a hedge: for his Father had neuer a
houſe but the Cage.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Valiant I am.

speech.speaker: Weauer.
speech.line: A muſt needs, for beggery is valiant.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: I am able to endure much.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: No queſtion of that: for I haue ſeene him whipt
three Market dayes together.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: I feare neither ſword, nor ﬁre.

speech.speaker: Wea.
speech.line: He neede not feare the ſword, for his Coate is of
proofe.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: But me thinks he ſhould ſtand in feare of ﬁre, be-
ing burnt i’th hand for ſtealing of Sheepe.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Be braue then, for your Captaine is Braue, and
Vowes Reformation. There ſhall be in England, ſeuen
halfe peny Loaues ſold for a peny: the three hoop’d pot,
ſhall haue ten hoopes, and I wil make it Fellony to drink
ſmall Beere. All the Realme ſhall be in Common, and in
Cheapſide ſhall my Palfrey go to graſſe: and when I am
King, as King I will be.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: God ſaue your Maieſty.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: I thanke you good people. There ſhall bee no
mony, all ſhall eate and drinke on my ſcore, and I will
apparrell them all in one Liuery, that they may agree like
Brothers, and worſhip me their Lord.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: The ﬁrſt thing we do, let’s kill all the Lawyers.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Nay, that I meane to do. Is not this a lamenta-
ble thing, that of the skin of an innocent Lambe ſhould
be made Parchment; that Parchment being ſcribeld ore,
ſhould vndoe a man. Some ſay the Bee ſtings, but I ſay,
’tis the Bees waxe: for I did but ſeale once to a thing, and
I was neuer mine owne man ſince. How now? Who’s
there?

speech.speaker: Weauer.
speech.line: The Clearke of Chartam: hee can write and
reade, and caſt accompt.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: O monſtrous.

speech.speaker: Wea.
speech.line: We tooke him ſetting of boyes Copies.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Here’s a Villaine.

speech.speaker: Wea.
speech.line: Ha’s a Booke in his pocket with red Letters in’t

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Nay then he is a Coniurer.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: Nay, he can make Obligations, and write Court
hand.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: I am ſorry for’t: The man is a proper man of
mine Honour: vnleſſe I ﬁnde him guilty he ſhall not die.
Come hither ſirrah, I muſt examine thee: What is thy
name?

speech.speaker: Clearke.
speech.line: Emanuell.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: They vſe to writ it on the top of Letters: ’Twill
go hard with you.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Let me alone: Doſt thou vſe to write thy name?
Or haſt thou a marke to thy ſelfe, like a honeſt plain dea-
ling man?

speech.speaker: Clearke.
speech.line: Sir I thanke God, I haue bin ſo well brought
vp, that I can write my name.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: He hath confeſt: away with him: he’s a Villaine
and a Traitor.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Away with him I ſay: Hang him with his Pen
and Inke-horne about his necke.

speech.speaker: Mich.
speech.line: Where’s our Generall?

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Heere I am thou particular fellow.

speech.speaker: Mich.
speech.line: Fly, ﬂy, ﬂy, Sir Humfrey Stafford and his brother
are hard by, with the Kings Forces.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Stand villaine, ſtand, or Ile fell thee downe: he
ſhall be encountred with a man as good as himſelfe. He
is but a Knight, is a?

speech.speaker: Mich.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: To equall him I will make my ſelfe a knight, pre-
ſently; Riſe vp Sir Iohn Mortimer. Now haue at him.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sir Humfrey Stafford, and his Brother, with Drum and Soldiers.

speech.speaker: Staf.
speech.line: Rebellious Hinds, the ﬁlth and ſcum of Kent,
Mark’d for the Gallowes: Lay your Weapons downe,
Home to your Cottages: forſake this Groome.
The King is mercifull, if you reuolt.

speech.speaker: Bro.
speech.line: But angry, wrathfull, and inclin’d to blood,
If you go forward: therefore yeeld, or dye.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: As for theſe ſilken-coated ſlaues I paſſe not,
It is to you good people, that I ſpeake,
Ouer whom (in time to come) I hope to raigne:
For I am rightfull heyre vnto the Crowne.

speech.speaker: Staff.
speech.line: Villaine, thy Father was a Playſterer,
And thou thy ſelfe a Sheareman, art thou not?

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: And Adam was a Gardiner.

speech.speaker: Bro.
speech.line: And what of that?

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Marry, this Edmund Mortimer Earle of March,
married the Duke of Clarence daughter, did he not?

speech.speaker: Staf.
speech.line: I ſir.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: By her he had two children at one birth.

speech.speaker: Bro.
speech.line: That’s falſe.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: I, there’s the queſtion; But I ſay, ’tis true:
The elder of them being put to nurſe,
Was by a begger-woman ſtolne away,
And ignorant of his birth and parentage,
Became a Bricklayer, when he came to age.
His ſonne am I, deny it if you can.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: Nay, ’tis too true, therefore he ſhall be King.

speech.speaker: Wea.
speech.line: Sir, he made a Chimney in my Fathers houſe, &
the brickes are aliue at this day to teſtiﬁe it: therefore
deny it not.

speech.speaker: Staf.
speech.line: And will you credit this baſe Drudges Wordes,
that ſpeakes he knowes not what.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: I marry will we: therefore get ye gone.

speech.speaker: Bro.
speech.line: Iacke Cade, the D. of York hath taught you this.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: He lyes, for I inuented it my ſelfe. Go too Sir-
rah, tell the King from me, that for his Fathers ſake Hen-
ry the ﬁft, (in whoſe time, boyes went to Span-counter
for French Crownes) I am content he ſhall raigne, but Ile
be Proteƈtor ouer him.

speech.speaker: Butcher.
speech.line: And furthermore, wee’l haue the Lord Sayes
head, for ſelling the Dukedome of Maine.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: And good reaſon: for thereby is England main’d
And faine to go with a ſtaffe, but that my puiſſance holds
it vp. Fellow-Kings, I tell you, that that Lord Say hath
gelded the Commonwealth, and made it an Eunuch: &
more then that, he can ſpeake French, and therefore hee is
a Traitor.

speech.speaker: Staf.
speech.line: O groſſe and miſerable ignorance.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Nay anſwer if you can: The Frenchmen are our
enemies: go too then, I ask but this: Can he that ſpeaks
with the tongue of an enemy, be a good Councellour, or
no?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: No, no, and therefore wee’l haue his head.

speech.speaker: Bro.
speech.line: Well, ſeeing gentle words will not preuayle,
Aſſaile them with the Army of the King.

speech.speaker: Staf.
speech.line: Herald away, and throughout euery Towne,
Proclaime them Traitors that are vp with Cade,
That thoſe which ﬂye before the battell ends,
May euen in their Wiues and Childrens ſight,
Be hang’d vp for example at their doores:
And you that be the Kings Friends follow me.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: And you that loue the Commons, follow me:
Now ſhew your ſelues men, ’tis for Liberty.
We will not leaue one Lord, one Gentleman:
Spare none, but ſuch as go in clouted ſhooen,
For they are thrifty honeſt men, and ſuch
As would (but that they dare not) take our parts.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: They are all in order, and march toward vs.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: But then are we in order, when we are moſt out
of order. Come, march forward.

scene.stagedir: Alarums to the ﬁght, wherein both the Staffords are ſlaine. Enter Cade and the reſt

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Where’s Dicke, the Butcher of Aſhford?

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: Heere ſir.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: They fell before thee like Sheepe and Oxen, &
thou behaued’ſt thy ſelfe, as if thou hadſt beene in thine
owne Slaughter-houſe: Therfore thus will I reward thee,
the Lent ſhall bee as long againe as it is, and thou ſhalt
haue a Licenſe to kill for a hundred lacking one.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: I deſire no more.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: And to ſpeake truth, thou deſeru’ſt no leſſe.
This Monument of the viƈtory will I beare, and the bo-
dies ſhall be dragg’d at my horſe heeles, till I do come to
London, where we will haue the Maiors ſword born be-
fore vs.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: If we meane to thriue, and do good, breake open
the Gaoles, and let out the Priſoners.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Feare not that I warrant thee. Come, let’s march
towards London.

scene.stagedir: Enter the King with a Supplication, and the Queene with Suffolkes head, the Duke of Buckingham, and the Lord Say.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Oft haue I heard that greefe ſoftens the mind,
And makes it fearefull and degenerate,
Thinke therefore on reuenge, and ceaſe to weepe.
But who can ceaſe to weepe, and looke on this.
Heere may his head lye on my throbbing breſt:
But where’s the body that I ſhould imbrace?

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: What anſwer makes your Grace to the Rebells
Supplication?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Ile ſend ſome holy Biſhop to intreat:
For God forbid, ſo many ſimple ſoules
Should periſh by the Sword. And I my ſelfe,
Rather then bloody Warre ſhall cut them ſhort,
Will parley with Iacke Cade their Generall.
But ſtay, Ile read it ouer once againe.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Ah barbarous villaines: Hath this louely face,
Rul’d like a wandering Plannet ouer me,
And could it not inforce them to relent,
That were vnworthy to behold the ſame.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Lord Say, Iacke Cade hath ſworne to haue thy
head.

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: I, but I hope your Highneſſe ſhall haue his.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How now Madam?
Still lamenting and mourning for Suffolkes death?
I feare me (Loue) if that I had beene dead,
Thou would’ſt not haue mourn’d ſo much for me.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: No my Loue, I ſhould not mourne, but dye for
thee.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How now? What newes? Why com’ſt thou in
ſuch haſte?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: The Rebels are in Southwarke: Fly my Lord:
Iacke Cade proclaimes himſelfe Lord Mortimer,
Deſcended from the Duke of Clarence houſe,
And calles your Grace Vſurper, openly,
And vowes to Crowne himſelfe in Weſtminſter.
His Army is a ragged multitude
Of Hindes and Pezants, rude and mercileſſe:
Sir Humfrey Stafford, and his Brothers death,
Hath giuen them heart and courage to proceede:
All Schollers, Lawyers, Courtiers, Gentlemen,
They call falſe Catterpillers, and intend their death.

speech.speaker: Kin.
speech.line: Oh graceleſſe men: they know not what they do.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: My gracious Lord, retire to Killingworth,
Vntill a power be rais’d to put them downe.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Ah were the Duke of Suffolke now aliue,
Theſe Kentiſh Rebels would be ſoone appeas’d.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Lord Say, the Traitors hateth thee,
Therefore away with vs to Killingworth.

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: So might your Graces perſon be in danger.
The ſight of me is odious in their eyes:
And therefore in this Citty will I ſtay,
And liue alone as ſecret as I may.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Iacke Cade hath gotten London-bridge.
The Citizens ﬂye and forſake their houſes:
The Raſcall people, thirſting after prey,
Ioyne with the Traitor, and they ioyntly ſweare
To ſpoyle the City, and your Royall Court.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: Then linger not my Lord, away, take horſe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Come Margaret, God our hope will ſuccor vs.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: My hope is gone, now Suffolke is deceaſt.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Farewell my Lord, truſt not the Kentiſh Rebels

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: Truſt no body for feare you betraid.

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: The truſt I haue, is in mine innocence,
And therefore am I bold and reſolute.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lord Scales vpon the Tower walking. Then enters two or three Citizens below.

speech.speaker: Scales.
speech.line: How now? Is Iacke Cade ſlaine?

speech.speaker: 1. Cit.
speech.line: No my Lord, nor likely to be ſlaine:
For they haue wonne the Bridge,
Killing all thoſe that withſtand them:
The L. Maior craues ayd of your Honor from the Tower
To defend the City from the Rebels.

speech.speaker: Scales.
speech.line: Such ayd as I can ſpare you ſhall command,
But I am troubled heere with them my ſelfe,
The Rebels haue aſſay’d to win the Tower.
But get you to Smithﬁeld, and gather head,
And thither I will ſend you Mathew Goffe.
Fight for your King, your Countrey, and your Liues,
And ſo farwell, for I muſt hence againe. Exeunt

scene.stagedir: Enter Iacke Cade and the reſt, and ſtrikes his ſtaffe on London ſtone.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Now is Mortimer Lord of this City,
And heere ſitting vpon London Stone,
I charge and command, that of the Cities coſt
The piſſing Conduit run nothing but Clarret Wine
This ﬁrſt yeare of our raigne.
And now henceforward it ſhall be Treaſon for any,
That calles me other then Lord Mortimer.

speech.speaker: Soul.
speech.line: Iacke Cade, Iacke Cade.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Knocke him downe there.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: If this Fellow be wiſe, hee’l neuer call yee Iacke
Cade more, I thinke he hath a very faire warning.

speech.speaker: Dicke.
speech.line: My Lord, there’s an Army gathered together
in Smithﬁeld.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Come, then let’s go ﬁght with them:
But ﬁrſt, go and ſet London Bridge on ﬁre,
And if you can, burne downe the Tower too.
Come, let’s away. Exeunt omnes.

scene.stagedir: Alarums. Mathew Goffe is ſlain, and all the reſt. Then enter Iacke Cade, with his Company.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: So ſirs: now go ſome and pull down the Sauoy:
Others to’th Innes of Court, downe with them all.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: I haue a ſuite vnto your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Bee it a Lordſhippe, thou ſhalt haue it for that
word.

speech.speaker: But.
speech.line: Onely that the Lawes of England may come out
of your mouth.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Maſſe ’twill be ſore Law then, for he was thruſt
in the mouth with a Speare, and ’tis not whole yet.

speech.speaker: Smith.
speech.line: Nay Iohn, it wil be ſtinking Law, for his breath
ſtinkes with eating toaſted cheeſe.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: I haue thought vpon it, it ſhall bee ſo. Away,
burne all the Records of the Realme, my mouth ſhall be
the Parliament of England.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Then we are like to haue biting Statutes
Vnleſſe his teeth be pull’d out.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: And hence-forward all things ſhall be in Com-
mon.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: My Lord, a prize, a prize, heeres the Lord Say,
which ſold the Townes in France. He that made vs pay
one and twenty Fifteenes, and one ſhilling to the pound,
the laſt Subſidie.

scene.stagedir: Enter George, with the Lord Say.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Well, hee ſhall be beheaded for it ten times:
Ah thou Say, thou Surge, nay thou Buckram Lord, now
art thou within point-blanke of our Iuriſdiƈtion Regall.
What canſt thou anſwer to my Maieſty, for giuing vp of
Normandie vnto Mounſieur Baſimecu, the Dolphine of
France? Be it knowne vnto thee by theſe preſence, euen
the preſence of Lord Mortimer, that I am the Beeſome
that muſt ſweepe the Court cleane of ſuch ﬁlth as thou
art: Thou haſt moſt traiterouſly corrupted the youth of
the Realme, in ereƈting a Grammar Schoole: and where-
as before, our Fore-fathers had no other Bookes but the
Score and the Tally, thou haſt cauſed printing to be vs’d,
and contrary to the King, his Crowne, and Dignity, thou
haſt built a Paper-Mill. It will be prooued to thy Face,
that thou haſt men about thee, that vſually talke of a
Nowne and a Verbe, and ſuch abhominable wordes, as
no Chriſtian eare can endure to heare. Thou haſt appoin-
ted Iuſtices of Peace, to call poore men before them, a-
bout matters they were not able to anſwer. Moreouer,
thou haſt put them in priſon, and becauſe they could not
reade, thou haſt hang’d them, when (indeede) onely for
that cauſe they haue beene moſt worthy to liue. Thou
doſt ride in a foot-cloth, doſt thou not?

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: What of that?

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Marry, thou ought’ſt not to let thy horſe weare
a Cloake, when honeſter men then thou go in their Hoſe
and Doublets.

speech.speaker: Dicke.
speech.line: And worke in their ſhirt to, as my ſelfe for ex-
ample, that am a butcher.

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: You men of Kent.

speech.speaker: Dic.
speech.line: What ſay you of Kent.

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: Nothing but this: ’Tis bona terra, mala gens.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Away with him, away with him, he ſpeaks La-
tine.

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: Heare me but ſpeake, and beare mee wher’e you
will:
Kent, in the Commentaries Cæſar writ,
Is term’d the ciuel’ſt place of all this Iſle:
Sweet is the Country, becauſe full of Riches,
The People Liberall, Valiant, Aƈtiue, Wealthy,
Which makes me hope you are not void of pitty.
I ſold not Maine, I loſt not Normandie,
Yet to recouer them would looſe my life:
Iuſtice with fauour haue I alwayes done,
Prayres and Teares haue mou’d me, Gifts could neuer.
When haue I ought exaƈted at your hands?
Kent to maintaine, the King, the Realme and you,
Large gifts haue I beſtow’d on learned Clearkes,
Becauſe my Booke preferr’d me to the King.
And ſeeing Ignorance is the curſe of God,
Knowledge the Wing wherewith we ﬂye to heauen.
Vnleſſe you be poſſeſt with diuelliſh ſpirits,
You cannot but forbeare to murther me:
This Tongue hath parlied vnto Forraigne Kings
For your behoofe.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Tut, when ſtruck’ſt thou one blow in the ﬁeld?

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: Great men haue reaching hands: oft haue I ſtruck
Thoſe that I neuer ſaw, and ſtrucke them dead.

speech.speaker: Geo.
speech.line: O monſtrous Coward! What, to come behinde
Folkes?

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: Theſe cheekes are pale for watching for your good

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Giue him a box o’th’ eare, and that wil make ’em
red againe.

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: Long ſitting to determine poore mens cauſes,
Hath made me full of ſickneſſe and diſeaſes.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Ye ſhall haue a hempen Candle then, & the help
of hatchet.

speech.speaker: Dicke.
speech.line: Why doſt thou quiuer man?

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: The Palſie, and not feare prouokes me.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Nay, he noddes at vs, as who ſhould ſay, Ile be
euen with you. Ile ſee if his head will ſtand ſteddier on
a pole, or no: Take him away, and behead him.

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: Tell me: wherein haue I offended moſt?
Haue I affeƈted wealth, or honor? Speake.
Are my Cheſts ﬁll’d vp with extorted Gold?
Is my Apparrell ſumptuous to behold?
Whom haue I iniur’d, that ye ſeeke my death?
Theſe hands are free from guiltleſſe bloodſhedding,
This breaſt from harbouring foule deceitfull thoughts.
O let me liue.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: I feele remorſe in my ſelfe with his words: but
Ile bridle it: he ſhall dye, and it bee but for pleading ſo
well for his life. Away with him, he ha’s a Familiar vn-
der his Tongue, he ſpeakes not a Gods name. Goe, take
him away I ſay, and ſtrike off his head preſently, and then
breake into his Sonne in Lawes houſe, Sir Iames Cromer,
and ſtrike off his head, and bring them both vppon two
poles hither.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: It ſhall be done.

speech.speaker: Say.
speech.line: Ah Countrimen: If when you make your prair’s,
God ſhould be ſo obdurate as your ſelues:
How would it fare with your departed ſoules,
And therefore yet relent, and ſaue my life.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Away with him, and do as I command ye: the
proudeſt Peere in the Realme, ſhall not weare a head on
his ſhoulders, vnleſſe he pay me tribute: there ſhall not
a maid be married, but ſhe ſhall pay to me her Mayden-
head ere they haue it: Men ſhall hold of mee in Capite.
And we charge and command, that their wiues be as free
as heart can wiſh, or tongue can tell.

speech.speaker: Dicke.
speech.line: My Lord,
When ſhall we go to Cheapſide, and take vp commodi-
ties vpon our billes?

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Marry preſently.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: O braue.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: But is not this brauer:
Let them kiſſe one another: For they lou’d well
When they were aliue. Now part them againe,
Leaſt they conſult about the giuing vp
Of ſome more Townes in France. Soldiers,
Deferre the ſpoile of the Citie vntill night:
For with theſe borne before vs, in ſteed of Maces,
Will we ride through the ſtreets, & at euery Corner
Haue them kiſſe. Away. Exit

scene.stagedir: Alarum, and Retreat. Enter againe Cade, and all his rabblement.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Vp Fiſh-ſtreete, downe Saint Magnes corner,
kill and knocke downe, throw them into Thames:
What noiſe is this I heare?
Dare any be ſo bold to ſound Retreat or Parley
When I command them kill?

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: I heere they be, that dare and will diſturb thee:
Know Cade, we come Ambaſſadors from the King
Vnto the Commons, whom thou haſt miſled,
And heere pronounce free pardon to them all,
That will forſake thee, and go home in peace.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: What ſay ye Countrimen, will ye relent
And yeeld to mercy, whil’ſt ’tis offered you,
Or let a rabble leade you to your deaths.
Who loues the King, and will imbrace his pardon,
Fling vp his cap, and ſay, God ſaue his Maieſty.
Who hateth him, and honors not his Father,
Henry the ﬁft, that made all France to quake,
Shake he his weapon at vs, and paſſe by.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: God ſaue the King, God ſaue the King.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: What Buckingham and Clifford are ye ſo braue?
And you baſe Pezants, do ye beleeue him, will you needs
be hang’d with your Pardons about your neckes? Hath
my ſword therefore broke through London gates, that
you ſhould leaue me at the White-heart in Southwarke.
I thought ye would neuer haue giuen out theſe Armes til
you had recouered your ancient Freedome. But you are
all Recreants and Daſtards, and delight to liue in ſlauerie
to the Nobility. Let them breake your backes with bur-
thens, take your houſes ouer your heads, rauiſh your
Wiues and Daughters before your faces. For me, I will
make ſhift for one, and ſo Gods Curſſe light vppon you
all.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Wee’l follow Cade,
Wee’l follow Cade.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Is Cade the ſonne of Henry the ﬁft,
That thus you do exclaime you’l go with him.
Will he conduƈt you through the heart of France,
And make the meaneſt of you Earles and Dukes?
Alas, he hath no home, no place to ﬂye too:
Nor knowes he how to liue, but by the ſpoile,
Vnleſſe by robbing of your Friends, and vs.
Wer’t not a ſhame, that whilſt you liue at iarre,
The fearfull French, whom you late vanquiſhed
Should make a ſtart ore-ſeas, and vanquiſh you?
Me thinkes alreadie in this ciuill broyle,
I ſee them Lording it in London ſtreets,
Crying Villiago vnto all they meete.
Better ten thouſand baſe-borne Cades miſcarry,
Then you ſhould ſtoope vnto a Frenchmans mercy.
To France, to France, and get what you haue loſt:
Spare England, for it is your Natiue Coaſt:
Henry hath mony, you are ſtrong and manly:
God on our ſide, doubt not of Viƈtorie.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: A Clifford, a Clifford,
Wee’l follow the King, and Clifford.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Was euer Feather ſo lightly blowne too & fro,
as this multitude? The name of Henry the ﬁft, hales them
to an hundred miſchiefes, and makes them leaue mee de-
ſolate. I ſee them lay their heades together to ſurprize
me. My ſword make way for me, for heere is no ſtaying:
in deſpight of the diuels and hell, haue through the verie
middeſt of you, and heauens and honor be witneſſe, that
no want of reſolution in mee, but onely my Followers
baſe and ignominious treaſons, makes me betake mee to
my heeles.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: What, is he ﬂed? Go ſome and follow him,
And he that brings his head vnto the King,
Shall haue a thouſand Crownes for his reward.
Follow me ſouldiers, wee’l deuiſe a meane,
To reconcile you all vnto the King.

scene.stagedir: Sound Trumpets. Enter King, Queene, and Somerſet on the Tarras.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Was euer King that ioy’d an earthly Throne,
And could command no more content then I?
No ſooner was I crept out of my Cradle,
But I was made a King, at nine months olde.
Was neuer Subieƈt long’d to be a King,
As I do long and wiſh to be a Subieƈt.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: Health and glad tydings to your Maieſty.

speech.speaker: Kin.
speech.line: Why Buckingham, is the Traitor Cade ſurpris’d?
Or is he but retir’d to make him ſtrong?

scene.stagedir: Enter Multitudes with Halters about their Neckes.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: He is ﬂed my Lord, and all his powers do yeeld,
And humbly thus with halters on their neckes,
Expeƈt your Highneſſe doome of life, or death.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then heauen ſet ope thy euerlaſting gates,
To entertaine my vowes of thankes and praiſe.
Souldiers, this day haue you redeem’d your liues,
And ſhew’d how well you loue your Prince & Countrey:
Continue ſtill in this ſo good a minde,
And Henry though he be infortunate,
Aſſure your ſelues will neuer be vnkinde:
And ſo with thankes, and pardon to you all,
I do diſmiſſe you to your ſeuerall Countries.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: God ſaue the King, God ſaue the King.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Pleaſe it your Grace to be aduertiſed,
The Duke of Yorke is newly come from Ireland,
And with a puiſſant and a mighty power
Of Gallow-glaſſes and ſtout Kernes,
Is marching hitherward in proud array,
And ſtill proclaimeth as he comes along,
His Armes are onely to remoue from thee
The Duke of Somerſet, whom he tearmes a Traitor.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thus ſtands my ſtate, ’twixt Cade and Yorke
diſtreſt,
Like to a Ship, that hauing ſcap’d a Tempeſt,
Is ſtraight way calme, and boorded with a Pyrate.
But now is Cade driuen backe, his men diſpierc’d,
And now is Yorke in Armes, to ſecond him.
I pray thee Buckingham go and meete him,
And aske him what’s the reaſon of theſe Armes:
Tell him, Ile ſend Duke Edmund to the Tower,
And Somerſet we will commit thee thither,
Vntill his Army be diſmiſt from him.

speech.speaker: Somerſet.
speech.line: My Lord,
Ile yeelde my ſelfe to priſon willingly,
Or vnto death, to do my Countrey good.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: In any caſe, be not to rough in termes,
For he is ﬁerce, and cannot brooke hard Language.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: I will my Lord, and doubt not ſo to deale,
As all things ſhall redound vnto your good.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Come wife, let’s in, and learne to gouern better,
For yet may England curſe my wretched raigne.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Fye on Ambitions: ﬁe on my ſelfe, that haue a
ſword, and yet am ready to famiſh. Theſe ﬁue daies haue
I hid me in theſe Woods, and durſt not peepe out, for all
the Country is laid for me: but now am I ſo hungry, that
if I might haue a Leaſe of my life for a thouſand yeares, I
could ſtay no longer. Wherefore on a Bricke wall haue
I climb’d into this Garden, to ſee if I can eate Graſſe, or
picke a Sallet another while, which is not amiſſe to coole
a mans ſtomacke this hot weather: and I think this word
Sallet was borne to do me good: for many a time but for
a Sallet, my braine-pan had bene cleft with a brown Bill;
and many a time when I haue beene dry, & branely mar-
ching, it hath ſeru’d me inſteede of a quart pot to drinke
in: and now the word Sallet muſt ſerue me to feed on.

speech.speaker: Iden.
speech.line: Lord, who would liue turmoyled in the Court,
And may enioy ſuch quiet walkes as theſe?
This ſmall inheritance my Father left me,
Contenteth me, and worth a Monarchy.
I ſeeke not to waxe great by others warning,
Or gather wealth I care not with what enuy:
Sufﬁceth, that I haue maintaines my ſtate,
And ſends the poore well pleaſed from my gate.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Heere’s the Lord of the ſoile come to ſeize me
for a ſtray, for entering his Fee-ſimple without leaue. A
Villaine, thou wilt betray me, and get a 1000. Crownes
of the King by carrying my head to him, but Ile make
thee eate Iron like an Oſtridge, and ſwallow my Sword
like a great pin ere thou and I part.

speech.speaker: Iden.
speech.line: Why rude Companion, whatſoere thou be,
I know thee not, why then ſhould I betray thee?
Is’t not enough to breake into my Garden,
And like a Theefe to come to rob my grounds:
Climbing my walles inſpight of me the Owner,
But thou wilt braue me with theſe ſawcie termes?

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Braue thee? I by the beſt blood that euer was
broach’d, and beard thee to. Looke on mee well, I haue
eate no meate theſe ﬁue dayes, yet come thou and thy
ﬁue men, and if I doe not leaue you all as dead as a doore
naile, I pray God I may neuer eate graſſe more.

speech.speaker: Iden.
speech.line: Nay, it ſhall nere be ſaid, while England ſtands,
That Alexander Iden an Eſquire of Kent,
Tooke oddes to combate a poore famiſht man.
Oppoſe thy ſtedfaſt gazing eyes to mine,
See if thou canſt out-face me with thy lookes:
Set limbe to limbe, and thou art farre the leſſer:
Thy hand is but a ﬁnger to my ﬁſt,
Thy legge a ſticke compared with this Truncheon,
My foote ſhall ﬁght with all the ſtrength thou haſt,
And if mine arme be heaued in the Ayre,
Thy graue is digg’d already in the earth:
As for words, whoſe greatneſſe anſwer’s words,
Let this my ſword report what ſpeech forbeares.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: By my Valour: the moſt compleate Champi-
on that euer I heard. Steele, if thou turne the edge, or
cut not out the burly bon’d Clowne in chines of Beefe,
ere thou ſleepe in thy Sheath, I beſeech Ioue on my knees
thou mayſt be turn’d to Hobnailes.
O I am ſlaine, Famine and no other hath ſlaine me, let ten
thouſand diuelles come againſt me, and giue me but the
ten meales I haue loſt, and I’de deﬁe them all. Wither
Garden, and be henceforth a burying place to all that do
dwell in this houſe, becauſe the vnconquered ſoule of
Cade is ﬂed.

speech.speaker: Iden.
speech.line: Is’t Cade that I haue ſlain, that monſtrous traitor?
Sword, I will hallow thee for this thy deede,
And hang thee o’re my Tombe, when I am dead.
Ne’re ſhall this blood be wiped from thy point,
But thou ſhalt weare it as a Heralds coate,
To emblaze the Honor that thy Maſter got.

speech.speaker: Cade.
speech.line: Iden farewell, and be proud of thy viƈtory: Tell
Kent from me, ſhe hath loſt her beſt man, and exhort all
the World to be Cowards: For I that neuer feared any,
am vanquiſhed by Famine, not by Valour.

speech.speaker: Id.
speech.line: How much thou wrong’ſt me, heauen be my iudge;
Die damned Wretch, the curſe of her that bare thee:
And as I thruſt thy body in with my ſword,
So wiſh I, I might thruſt thy ſoule to hell.
Hence will I dragge thee headlong by the heeles
Vnto a dunghill, which ſhall be thy graue,
And there cut off thy moſt vngracious head,
Which I will beare in triumph to the King,
Leauing thy trunke for Crowes to feed vpon.

scene.stagedir: Enter Yorke, and his Army of Iriſh, with Drum and Colours.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: From Ireland thus comes York to claim his right,
And plucke the Crowne from feeble Henries head.
Ring Belles alowd, burne Bonﬁres cleare and bright
To entertaine great Englands lawfull King.
Ah Sanƈta Maieſtas! who would not buy thee deere?
Let them obey, that knowes not how to Rule.
This hand was made to handle nought but Gold.
I cannot giue due aƈtion to my words,
Except a Sword or Scepter ballance it.
A Scepter ſhall it haue, haue I a ſoule,
On which Ile toſſe the Fleure-de-Luce of France.
Whom haue we heere? Buckingham to diſturbe me?
The king hath ſent him ſure: I muſt diſſemble.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: Yorke, if thou meaneſt wel, I greet thee well.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Humfrey of Buckingham, I accept thy greeting.
Art thou a Meſſenger, or come of pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: A Meſſenger from Henry, our dread Liege,
To know the reaſon of theſe Armes in peace.
Or why, thou being a Subieƈt, as I am,
Againſt thy Oath, and true Allegeance ſworne,
Should raiſe ſo great a power without his leaue?
Or dare to bring thy Force ſo neere the Court?

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Scarſe can I ſpeake, my Choller is ſo great.
Oh I could hew vp Rockes, and ﬁght with Flint,
I am ſo angry at theſe abieƈt tearmes.
And now like Aiax Telamonius,
On Sheepe or Oxen could I ſpend my furie.
I am farre better borne then is the king:
More like a King, more Kingly in my thoughts.
But I muſt make faire weather yet a while,
Till Henry be more weake, and I more ſtrong.
Buckingham, I prethee pardon me,
That I haue giuen no anſwer all this while:
My minde was troubled with deepe Melancholly.
The cauſe why I haue brought this Armie hither,
Is to remoue proud Somerſet from the King,
Seditious to his Grace, and to the State.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: That is too much preſumption on thy part:
But if thy Armes be to no other end,
The King hath yeelded vnto thy demand:
The Duke of Somerſet is in the Tower.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Vpon thine Honor is he Priſoner?

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Vpon mine Honor he is Priſoner.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Then Buckingham I do diſmiſſe my Powres.
Souldiers, I thanke you all: diſperſe your ſelues:
Meet me to morrow in S. Georges Field,
You ſhall haue pay, and euery thing you wiſh.
And let my Soueraigne, vertuous Henry,
Command my eldeſt ſonne, nay all my ſonnes,
As pledges of my Fealtie and Loue,
Ile ſend them all as willing as I liue:
Lands, Goods, Horſe, Armor, any thing I haue
Is his to vſe, ſo Somerſet may die.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: Yorke, I commend this kinde ſubmiſſion,
We twaine will go into his Highneſſe Tent.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Buckingham, doth Yorke intend no harme to vs
That thus he marcheth with thee arme in arme?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: In all ſubmiſſion and humility,
Yorke doth preſent himſelfe vnto your Highneſſe.

speech.speaker: K.
speech.line: Then what intends theſe Forces thou doſt bring?

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: To heaue the Traitor Somerſet from hence,
And ﬁght againſt that monſtrous Rebell Cade,
Who ſince I heard to be diſcomﬁted.

speech.speaker: Iden.
speech.line: If one ſo rude, and of ſo meane condition
May paſſe into the preſence of a King:
Loe, I preſent your Grace a Traitors head,
The head of Cade, whom I in combat ſlew.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: The head of Cade? Great God, how iuſt art thou?
Oh let me view his Viſage being dead,
That liuing wrought me ſuch exceeding trouble.
Tell me my Friend, art thou the man that ſlew him?

speech.speaker: Iden.
speech.line: I was, an’t like your Maieſty.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How art thou call’d? And what is thy degree?

speech.speaker: Iden.
speech.line: Alexander Iden, that’s my name,
A poore Eſquire of Kent, that loues his King.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: So pleaſe it you my Lord, ’twere not amiſſe
He were created Knight for his good ſeruice.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Iden, kneele downe, riſe vp a Knight:
We giue thee for reward a thouſand Markes,
And will, that thou henceforth attend on vs.

speech.speaker: Iden.
speech.line: May Iden liue to merit ſuch a bountie,
And neuer liue but true vnto his Liege.

speech.speaker: K.
speech.line: See Buckingham, Somerſet comes with th’ Queene,
Go bid her hide him quickly from the Duke.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: For thouſand Yorkes he ſhall not hide his head,
But boldly ſtand, and front him to his face.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: How now? is Somerſet at libertie?
Then Yorke vnlooſe thy long impriſoned thoughts,
And let thy tongue be equall with thy heart.
Shall I endure the ſight of Somerſet?
Falſe King, why haſt thou broken faith with me,
Knowing how hardly I can brooke abuſe?
King did I call thee? No: thou art not King:
Not ﬁt to gouerne and rule multitudes,
Which dar’ſt not, no nor canſt not rule a Traitor.
That Head of thine doth not become a Crowne:
Thy Hand is made to graspe a Palmers ſtaffe,
And not to grace an awefull Princely Scepter.
That Gold, muſt round engirt theſe browes of mine,
Whoſe Smile and Frowne, like to Achilles Speare
Is able with the change, to kill and cure.
Heere is hand to hold a Scepter vp,
And with the ſame to aƈte controlling Lawes:
Giue place: by heauen thou ſhalt rule no more
O’re him, whom heauen created for thy Ruler.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: O monſtrous Traitor! I arreſt thee Yorke
Of Capitall Treaſon ’gainſt the King and Crowne:
Obey audacious Traitor, kneele for Grace.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: Wold’ſt haue me kneele? Firſt let me ask of thee,
If they can brooke I bow a knee to man:
Sirrah, call in my ſonne to be my bale:
I know ere they will haue me go to Ward,
They’l pawne their ſwords of my infranchiſement.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Call hither Clifford, bid him come amaine,
To ſay, if that the Baſtard boyes of Yorke
Shall be the Surety for their Traitor Father.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: O blood-beſpotted Neopolitan,
Out-caſt of Naples, Englands bloody Scourge,
The ſonnes of Yorke, thy betters in their birth,
Shall be their Fathers baile, and bane to thoſe
That for my Surety will refuſe the Boyes.
See where they come, Ile warrant they’l make it good.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: And here comes Clifford to deny their baile.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Health, and all happineſſe to my Lord the King.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: I thanke thee Clifford: Say, what newes with thee?
Nay, do not fright vs with an angry looke:
We are thy Soueraigne Clifford, kneele againe;
For thy miſtaking ſo, We pardon thee.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: This is my King Yorke, I do not miſtake,
But thou miſtakes me much to thinke I do,
To Bedlem with him, is the man growne mad.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I Clifford, a Bedlem and ambitious humor
Makes him oppoſe himſelfe againſt his King.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: He is a Traitor, let him to the Tower,
And chop away that faƈtious pate of his.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: He is arreſted, but will not obey:
His ſonnes (he ſayes) ſhall giue their words for him.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Will you not Sonnes?

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: I Noble Father, if our words will ſerue.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And if words will not, then our Weapons ſhal.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Why what a brood of Traitors haue we heere?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Looke in a Glaſſe, and call thy Image ſo.
I am thy King, and thou a falſe-heart Traitor:
Call hither to the ſtake my two braue Beares,
That with the very ſhaking of their Chaines,
They may aſtoniſh theſe fell-lurking Curres,
Bid Salsbury and Warwicke come to me.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Earles of Warwicke, and Salisbury.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Are theſe thy Beares? Wee’l bate thy Bears to death,
And manacle the Berard in their Chaines,
If thou dar’ſt bring them to the bayting place.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Oft haue I ſeene a hot ore-weening Curre,
Run backe and bite, becauſe he was with-held,
Who being ſuffer’d with the Beares fell paw,
Hath clapt his taile, betweene his legges and cride,
And ſuch a peece of ſeruice will you do,
If you oppoſe your ſelues to match Lord Warwicke.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Hence heape of wrath, foule indigeſted lumpe,
As crooked in thy manners, as thy ſhape.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Nay we ſhall heate you thorowly anon.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Take heede leaſt by your heate you burne your
ſelues:

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why Warwicke, hath thy knee forgot to bow?
Old Salsbury, ſhame to thy ſiluer haire,
Thou mad miſleader of thy brain-ſicke ſonne,
What wilt thou on thy death-bed play the Rufﬁan?
And ſeeke for ſorrow with thy Speƈtacles?
Oh where is Faith? Oh, where is Loyalty?
If it be baniſht from the froſtie head,
Where ſhall it ﬁnde a harbour in the earth?
Wilt thou go digge a graue to ﬁnde out Warre,
And ſhame thine honourable Age with blood?
Why art thou old, and want’ſt experience?
Or wherefore doeſt abuſe it, if thou haſt it?
For ſhame in dutie bend thy knee to me,
That bowes vnto the graue with mickle age.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: My Lord, I haue conſidered with my ſelfe
The Title of this moſt renowned Duke,
And in my conſcience, do repute his grace
The rightfull heyre to Englands Royall ſeate.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Haſt thou not ſworne Allegeance vnto me?

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: I haue.

speech.speaker: Ki.
speech.line: Canſt thou diſpenſe with heauen for ſuch an oath?

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: It is great ſinne, to ſweare vnto a ſinne:
But greater ſinne to keepe a ſinfull oath:
Who can be bound by any ſolemne Vow
To do a murd’rous deede, to rob a man,
To force a ſpotleſſe Virgins Chaſtitie,
To reaue the Orphan of his Patrimonie,
To wring the Widdow from her cuſtom’d right,
And haue no other reaſon for this wrong,
But that he was bound by a ſolemne Oath?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: A ſubtle Traitor needs no Sophiſter.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Call Buckingham, and bid him arme himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Call Buckingham, and all the friends thou haſt,
I am reſolu’d for death and dignitie.

speech.speaker: Old Clif.
speech.line: The ﬁrſt I warrant thee, if dreames proue true

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: You were beſt to go to bed, and dreame againe,
To keepe thee from the Tempeſt of the ﬁeld.

speech.speaker: Old Clif.
speech.line: I am reſolu’d to beare a greater ſtorme,
Then any thou canſt coniure vp to day:
And that Ile write vpon thy Burgonet,
Might I but know thee by thy houſed Badge.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Now by my Fathers badge, old Neuils Creſt,
The rampant Beare chain’d to the ragged ſtaffe,
This day Ile weare aloft my Burgonet,
As on a Mountaine top, the Cedar ſhewes,
That keepes his leaues inſpight of any ſtorme,
Euen io affright thee with the view thereof.

speech.speaker: Old Clif.
speech.line: And from thy Burgonet Ile rend thy Beare,
And tread it vnder foot with all contempt,
Deſpight the Bearard, that proteƈts the Beare.

speech.speaker: Yo. Clif.
speech.line: And ſo to Armes viƈtorious Father,
To quell the Rebels, and their Complices.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Fie, Charitie for ſhame, ſpeake not in ſpight,
For you ſhall ſup with Ieſu Chriſt to night.

speech.speaker: Yo. Clif.
speech.line: Foule ſtygmaticke that’s more then thou
canſt tell.

speech.speaker: Ric.
speech.line: If not in heauen, you’l ſurely ſup in hell.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Clifford of Cumberland, ’tis Warwicke calles:
And if thou doſt not hide thee from the Beare,
Now when the angrie Trumpet ſounds alarum,
And dead mens cries do ﬁll the emptie ayre,
Clifford I ſay, come forth and ﬁght with me,
Proud Northerne Lord, Clifford of Cumberland,
Warwicke is hoarſe with calling thee to armes.
