speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: How now my Noble Lord? What all a-foot.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: The deadly handed Clifford ſlew my Steed:
But match to match I haue encountred him,
And made a prey for Carrion Kytes and Crowes
Euen of the bonnie beaſt he loued ſo well.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Of one or both of vs the time is come.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Hold Warwick: ſeek thee out ſome other chace
For I my ſelfe muſt hunt this Deere to death.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Then nobly Yorke, ’tis for a Crown thou ﬁghtſt:
As I intend Clifford to thriue to day,
It greeues my ſoule to leaue thee vnaſſail’d.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: What ſeeſt thou in me Yorke?
Why doſt thou pauſe?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: With thy braue bearing ſhould I be in loue,
But that thou art ſo faſt mine enemie.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Nor ſhould thy proweſſe want praiſe & eſteeme,
But that ’tis ſhewne ignobly, and in Treaſon.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: So let it helpe me now againſt thy ſword,
As I in iuſtice, and true right expreſſe it.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: My ſoule and bodie on the aƈtion both.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: A dreadfull lay, addreſſe thee inſtantly.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: La ﬁn Corrone les eumenes.

speech.speaker: Yor.
speech.line: Thus Warre hath giuen thee peace, for ӳ art ſtill,
Peace with his ſoule, heauen if it be thy will.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Shame and Confuſion all is on the rout,
Feare frames diſorder, and diſorder wounds
Where it ſhould guard. O Warre, thou ſonne of hell,
Whom angry heauens do make their miniſter,
Throw in the frozen boſomes of our part,
Hot Coales of Vengeance. Let no Souldier ﬂye.
He that is truly dedicate to Warre,
Hath no ſelfe-loue: nor he that loues himſelfe,
Hath not eſſentially, but by circumſtance
The name of Valour. O let the vile world end,
And the premiſed Flames of the Laſt day,
Knit earth and heauen together.
Now let the generall Trumpet blow his blaſt,
Particularities, and pettie ſounds
To ceaſe. Was’t thou ordain’d (deere Father)
To looſe thy youth in peace, and to atcheeue
The Siluer Liuery of aduiſed Age,
And in thy Reuerence, and thy Chaire-dayes, thus
To die in Rufﬁan battell? Euen at this ſight,
My heart is turn’d to ſtone: and while ’tis mine,
It ſhall be ſtony. Yorke, not our old men ſpares:
No more will I their Babes, Teares Virginall,
Shall be to me, euen as the Dew to Fire,
And Beautie, that the Tyrant oft reclaimes,
Shall to my ﬂaming wrath, be Oyle and Flax:
Henceforth, I will not haue to do with pitty.
Meet I an infant of the houſe of Yorke,
Into as many gobbits will I cut it
As wilde Medea yong Abſirtis did.
In cruelty, will I ſeeke out my Fame.
Come thou new ruine of olde Cliffords houſe:
As did Æneas old Anchyſes beare,
So beare I thee vpon my manly ſhoulders:
But then, Æneas bare a liuing loade;
Nothing ſo heauy as theſe woes of mine.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard, and Somerſet to ﬁght.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: So lye thou there:
For vnderneath an Ale-houſe paltry ſigne,
The Caſtle in S. Albons, Somerſet
Hath made the Wizard famous in his death:
Sword, hold thy temper; Heart, be wrathfull ſtill:
Prieſts pray for enemies, but Princes kill.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Away my Lord, you are ſlow, for ſhame away.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Can we outrun the Heauens? Good Margaret
ſtay.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: What are you made of? You’l nor ﬁght nor ﬂy:
Now is it manhood, wiſedome, and defence,
To giue the enemy way, and to ſecure vs
By what we can, which can no more but ﬂye.
If you be tane, we then ſhould ſee the bottome
Of all our Fortunes: but if we haply ſcape,
(As well we may, if not through your negleƈt)
We ſhall to London get, where you are lou’d,
And where this breach now in our Fortunes made
May readily be ſtopt.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: But that my hearts on future miſcheefe ſet,
I would ſpeake blaſphemy ere bid you ﬂye:
But ﬂye you muſt: Vncureable diſcomﬁte
Reignes in the hearts of all our preſent parts.
Away for your releefe, and we will liue
To ſee their day, and them our Fortune giue.
Away my Lord, away. Exeunt

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Retreat. Enter Yorke, Richard, Warwicke, and Soldiers, with Drum & Colours.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Of Salsbury, who can report of him,
That Winter Lyon, who in rage forgets
Aged contuſions, and all bruſh of Time:
And like a Gallant, in the brow of youth,
Repaires him with Occaſion. This happy day
Is not it ſelfe, nor haue we wonne one foot,
If Salsbury be loſt.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: My Noble Father:
Three times to day I holpe him to his horſe,
Three times beſtrid him: Thrice I led him off,
Perſwaded him from any further aƈt:
But ſtill where danger was, ſtill there I met him,
And like rich hangings in a homely houſe,
So was his Will, in his old feeble body,
But Noble as he is, looke where he comes.

speech.speaker: Sal.
speech.line: Now by my Sword, well haſt thou fought to day:
By’ th’ Maſſe ſo did we all. I thanke you Richard.
God knowes how long it is I haue to liue:
And it hath pleas’d him that three times to day
You haue defended me from imminent death.
Well Lords, we haue not got that which we haue,
’Tis not enough our foes are this time ﬂed,
Being oppoſites of ſuch repayring Nature.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I know our ſafety is to follow them,
For (as I heare) the King is ﬂed to London,
To call a preſent Court of Parliament:
Let vs purſue him ere the Writs go forth.
What ſayes Lord Warwicke, ſhall we after them?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: After them: nay before them if we can:
Now by my hand (Lords) ’twas a glorious day.
Saint Albons battell wonne by famous Yorke,
Shall be eterniz’d in all Age to come.
Sound Drumme and Trumpets, and to London all,
And more ſuch dayes as theſe, to vs befall.
